    1. group

Annotation Type Operator

@Documented @Target(TYPE) @Retention(SOURCE) public @interface Operator
Annotation used by classes to make TensorFlow operations conveniently accessible via org.tensorflow.op.Ops or one of its groups.

An annotation processor (org.tensorflow.processor.OperatorProcessor) builds the Ops class by aggregating all classes annotated as @Operators. Each annotated class must have at least one public static factory method named create that accepts a Scope as its first argument. The processor then adds a convenience method in the Ops class. For example: 

@Operator
public final class MyOp implements Op {
  @Endpoint
  public static MyOp create(Scope scope, Operand<?> operand) {
    ...
  }
}

results in a method in the Ops class 

import org.tensorflow.op.Ops;
...
Ops ops = Ops.create(graph);
...
ops.myOp(operand);
// and has exactly the same effect as calling
// MyOp.create(ops.getScope(), operand);

  • Optional Element Summary

    Optional Elements
    Modifier and Type
    Optional Element
    Description
    String
    group
    Specify an optional group within the Ops class.
    String
    name
    Name for the wrapper method used in the Ops class.

  • Element Details

    • group

      String group
      Specify an optional group within the Ops class.

      By default, an annotation processor will create convenience methods directly in the Ops class. An annotated operator may optionally choose to place the method within a group. For example: 

      @Operator(group="math")
public final class Add extends RawOp implements Operand {
  ...
}

      results in the add method placed within a math group within the Ops class. 

      ops.math.add(...);

      The operator can also be classified into subgroups of another group, following a semantic similar to Java packages. For example: 

      @Operator(group="data.experimental")
public final class MyDataset extends RawOp implements Operand {
  ...
}

      results in the add method placed within a experimental group within the DataOps group class. 

      ops.data.experimental.myDataset(...);

      The group name must be a valid Java package name.

      Default:
      ""

    • name

      String name
      Name for the wrapper method used in the Ops class.

      By default, a processor derives the method name in the Ops class from the class name of the operator. This attribute allow you to provide a different name instead. For example: 

      @Operator(name="myOperation")
public final class MyRealOperation implements Operand {
  public static MyRealOperation create(...)
}

      results in this method added to the Ops class 

      ops.myOperation(...);
// and is the same as calling
// MyRealOperation.create(...)

      The name must be a valid Java identifier.

      Default:
      ""
